article.title: Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen steering and Bell nonlocality of two macroscopic mechanical oscillators in optomechanical systems

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1: **Question:** This figure shows the steady-state entanglement and steering of two mechanical resonators as a function of different parameters. What key factor leads to the difference between steerings G1→2 and G2→1?
choices: The different temperatures of the two mechanical resonators.
The difference in the effective optomechanical couplings G1 and G2.
The different cavity decay rates κ1 and κ2.
The phase shift θ of the light in the feedback loop.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2: **Question:**  This figure illustrates the time evolution of steering and entanglement for two mechanical resonators at various temperatures. What is the relationship between two-way steering and entanglement based on these results?
choices: Two-way steering is present only when entanglement surpasses a specific threshold (EN > ln3).
Two-way steering is always present regardless of the entanglement level.
Entanglement occurs only when there is two-way steering.
There is no clear relationship between two-way steering and entanglement.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3: **Question:**  Figure 3 presents the time evolution of Bell violation (|Bmax|) for two mechanical resonators. What do the results indicate about the impact of mechanical damping (γ) on Bell violation with parity detection?
choices: Mechanical damping has negligible impact on Bell violation.
Increasing mechanical damping slightly enhances Bell violation.
Bell violation is robust against mechanical damping.
Even a small increase in mechanical damping significantly reduces Bell violation.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4: **Question:** This figure depicts a contour plot of |Bmax| as a function of mechanical damping rate (γ) and cavity decay rate (κ) for the dynamical case. Which statement is true based on the observed relationship between these parameters and Bell violation?
choices: Bell violation increases with increasing cavity decay rate.
Bell violation is robust against both mechanical damping and cavity decay rates.
Bell violation requires extremely low mechanical damping but is less sensitive to cavity decay rate.
High mechanical damping rate and low cavity decay rate are optimal for observing Bell violation.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5: **Question:** This figure shows the Bell violation with on-off detection in the steady state. What is the primary advantage of using on-off detection compared to parity detection for observing Bell violation?
choices: On-off detection yields larger Bell violation than parity detection.
On-off detection requires lower environmental temperature for Bell violation.
On-off detection is less sensitive to cavity losses compared to parity detection.
On-off detection is more sensitive to mechanical damping compared to parity detection.
